newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia rubber ends up but buying stays scarce.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia rubber ends up but buying stays scarce.

text.p: Malaysian rubber prices retained midday gains to end higher on the back of strong Tokyo futures, dealers said.
But trading was featureless and dull with both buyers and sellers not eager to commit, dealers said.

At the close, the Malaysian Rubber Exchange and Licensing Board (MRELB) quoted market indicator price for November RSS 1 buyer at 310.50 cents ($1.24) a kg, up half cent from Friday. November SMR 20 buyer was unchanged at 306.50.
Traders offered the SMR 20 at 305 cents, SMR10 at 306, SMR 5 at 316, SMR L at 342, SMR CV at 363 and drum latex at 235.
"I'll call it the Monday blues if the market hasn't been so bad this month," said a dealer.

Traders said buyers were looking at lower prices while producers were trying to hold at current levels. Rains since early October have seen little tapping activity at rubber estates, and producers are unhappy that this has not converted into higher prices at the market.
The INRO five-day average fell to 238.69 Malaysian/Singapore cents per kg on Oct 18 from 238.77 on Oct 17. The daily indicator fell to 238.98 from 238.77 previously.
